content: layer the unused yarn needs to be in back when you want to make a stitch on the back layer the unused yarn needs to be in the front for double-stockinette the most common double-knit fabric this means you bring all the yarn to the back knit with the colour for the front then bring all the yarns to the front and purl with the colour for the back in the cuff part of the chart will ask you to knit both stitches within a pair for the first stitch the front layer you ll have both yarns in back and you ll knit with the colour on the chart then you ll bring just that one yarn to the front and you ll knit with the second colour the chart will also ask you to purl both stitches in a pair for this you ll start with the yarnsseparated withthefirstcolourinfrontandthesecondcolourinback purlwiththefirstcolour thenbringthesecond colour to the front and then purl with the second colour some people who double-knit do so by only carrying one yarn at a time working some stitches with that colour and slipping the rest then they redo the row with another colour working different stitches and again slipping any unworked stitches this has the advantage that you don t need to be comfortable carrying multiple yarns at once but it has the downside that you have to do each row multiple times for this sock you ll probably want to carry both yarns together due to the intarsia twists when it s time to do an intarsia twist you ll need all four yarns together so the slip-stitch method will require you to do each 1/3 of the row twice causing you to back up 3 times per row norman schwarze has a youtube video demonstrating the basics https //www youtube com/watch v=uqkzr-2twca cast-on thispatternbeginswiththeitaliantwo-colourcastonusingthesmallerneedles whichsuzannebryanhasayoutubevideo to demonstrate https //www youtube com/watch v=wnnnkam5xsy i picked this cast on because it s stretchier than the two-colour long-tail cast on if you have another preferred stretchy cast on for two colours feel free to substitute decreases in most double-knitting decreases are paired between the front and back layers of the fabric because the stitches on the needles alternate between front- and back-layer stitches you ll first have to reorder the stitches to get both front-layer stitches together and both back-layer stitches together then you can do the decrease on the front and then you can do the decrease on the back alasdair post-quinn has a video on his youtube channel describing both decreases used in this sock https //www youtube com/watch v=g5vakjtoyiw intarsia as with single-layer intarsia when you stop working with one pair of colour s and pick up the next you ll normally want totwistalltheyarnsaroundeachother whetheryou reknittingright-handedorleft-handed you llhaveonepairofcolours on the left and one pair on the right bring all four yarns to the front of the work going under/between the needles if any yarnshadbeenbehind andcrossthemover
